biogHist.abstract: St Mary's Mission of Hope opened in Adelaide in 1904. Run by the Church of England it took in homeless girls, many from the Destitute Asylum. In 1922 toddlers were admitted and in 1930 teenagers were accommodated. During the 1940s Aboriginal girls from the Northern Territory were transferred to the Home. The Home changed its name to St Mary's Home for Children in 1953.
biogHist.p: St Mary's Mission of Hope opened in 1904 at 154 Halifax Street, Adelaide. It was run by the Church of England with the primary aim to rescue homeless girls from the Destitute Asylum. An article in the Adelaide Church Guardian in 1907 described the aims as follows:

'The efforts of the lady workers are chiefly directed at bringing under influence of the mission the girls in the infirmary of the destitute asylum, and sheltering them after they leave that institution until suitable situations can be procured for them. By this means, many girls have been restored to the paths of rectitude, who would otherwise have been left to sink into hopeless degradation and vice'
Shortly after opening, the Home moved a few buildings along the street to No. 222. Both of these former premises have since been demolished.

At the home girls were sheltered, counselled and assisted to find employment. In its first 18 years, the Home took in mainly young girls, some of whom were pregnant. Those who had already given birth were allowed to bring their children with them. The Mission assisted the girls to find jobs where they could take their babies, or if this was not possible, arranged for babies to be fostered or adopted.

Between 1909 and 1916, 246 girls passed through the Mission. Many of these were girls who did not qualify for admission to the House of Mercy at Walkerville which, among other rules, required potential residents to be recommended by a clergyman.

In 1922 the focus of the Mission of Hope on rescue work changed when Miss Jean Mills who worked with the Lady Victoria Buxton Girls Club brought a number of small children into the Home. From this time the St Mary's began to take in children of toddler age who were unable to be cared for by their families or who had been charged as neglected and made wards of the state. An article in the Adelaide Church Guardian in 1935 explained that that the focus changed because Miss Mills believed that 'to succeed in rescue work among younger girls, it was necessary to begin with little children'.

During this period, the home accommodated between 25 and 30 children of pre-school and early school age, offering shelter and religious education. For schooling, children attended the Free Kindergarten, St John's Day School on Halifax Street and after its closure, the Flinders Street School.

The management committee of St Mary's Mission of Hope often struggled with lack of funds and relied primarily on charitable donations. From 1936 the St Mary's Mission of Hope operated in cooperation with The Orphan Home at Mitcham. While St Mary's took charge of toddlers and teenagers, the Orphan Home, later known as Farr House, took in children of school age. As part of the agreement between the two Home management committees, the Orphan Home provided a loan to St Mary's to assist with renovations which included the building of four new dormitories. During the 1940s, in an arrangement with the Northern Territory Native Affairs Branch, a number of Aboriginal girls were sent from the Northern Territory to St Mary's. The Home was paid a subsidy by the Branch for their care.

In 1953 the management committee of St Mary's decided to return to caring for only pre-school children, aged between two and six. In recognition of this change, the name of the Home was changed to St Mary's Home for Children.

chronItem.event: Address - St Mary's Mission of Hope was situated at 154 Halifax Street, Adelaide
Address - St Mary's Mission of Hope was situated at 222 Halifax Street, Adelaide

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Church of England in Australia and Tasmania (1788 - 1981)
Visitors' reports, St Mary's Mission of Hope/St Mary's Home for Children (1949 - 1973)

descriptiveNote.p: Held at the Anglican Archives. Reports from the visitor appointed each month to inspect the home. Names of children are mentioned.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Secretary's reports, St Mary's Mission of Hope/St Mary's Home for Children (1941 - 1963)
Minutes of the management committee, St Mary's Mission of Hope/St Mary's Home for Children (1936 - 1975)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Anglican Archives. These handwritten and typed minutes discuss admissions and discharges, health issues and transfers of children as well as policies, home maintenance, staffing issues and other matters.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Matron's reports, St Mary's Mission of Hope/St Mary's Home for Children (1941 - 1970)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Anglican Archives. These reports from the Matron of the Home discuss admissions, discharges, health of children and other matters.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: January 1909 Admission Book, St Mary's Mission of Hope (1909 - 1946)

descriptiveNote.p: Held at the Anglican Archives. This admission book is a black foolscap book containing general admission information for children entering the Home.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Miscellaneous Correspondence and General Papers, St Mary's Mission of Hope (1930 - 1952)

descriptiveNote.p: Held at the State Library of South Australia. These files contain correspondence and papers relating to many aspects of the running of the Home.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Annual reports, St Mary's Mission of Hope (1906 - 1947)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the State Library of South Australia. These yearly reports cover developments during the year. They include some information regarding children and some photographs.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Photographs, Anglican Church/Church of England Homes (1860? - 1982?)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Anglican Archives. These photographs of Anglican Homes include photographs of St Mary's in its different locations.

During the 1930s the home operated in cooperation with The Orphan Home at Mitcham, also known as Farr House. It took charge of toddlers and teenagers while the Orphan Home took mostly children of school age.

During the 1930s St Mary's Mission of Hope operated in conjunction with the Orphan Home and, as it was later known, Farr House. St Mary's took charge of toddlers and teenagers and the Orphan Home took mostly children of school age.
St Mary's Mission of Hope took over the role of caring for babies and infants in 1945 when the Babies' Home, Walkerville, closed.
